properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Extreme heat is expected today and tomorrow. A hot airmass is bringing temperatures above 30 degrees for today and near 30 degrees for tomorrow with minimum temperatures near 18 degrees tonight. Cooler air will be arriving on Friday. ### The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-18T01:30:07-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-17T09:31:07-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0880945321.2020
Area: Fort Albany, Moosonee
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Planned Sasktel Service Outage In Pinehouse
properties.Summary:
Description: On June 19th, from 12:00 am (midnight) until approximately 6:00 am, SaskTel crews will be performing maintenance work on the network infrastructure serving the Northern Village of Pinehouse. During that timeframe, SaskTel Internet, Wireless, and Landline Phone services will be unavailable in and around the village.
Expires: 2020-06-19T11:00:00-06:00
Originated from CAP Alert: SK SaskTel, 2020-06-17T10:07:44-06:00, 3B1A573A-0A76-2D57-4E96-8894F0D0AFF2
Area: Northern Village of Pinehouse
properties.Author: SK SaskTel

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Temperatures reaching 29 to 32 degrees Celsius with humidex in the mid to high thirties combined with overnight lows in the upper teens to low twenties are expected for today and tonight. A cooler airmass will arrive on Thursday from the west. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of hot weather is expected for the end of the week. Time span: Thursday and Friday, possibly Saturday. Maximum Temperature Thursday: 30 to 32 degrees Celsius (Humidex 36) Minimum Temperature Thursday night: 17 to 19 degrees Celsius Maximum Temperature Friday: 33 degrees Celsius (Humidex 38) Locations: Inland areas of Nova Scotia Remarks: A very warm airmass will move into Nova Scotia today giving maximum temperatures inland near 28 degrees Celsius. Hot weather is expected on Thursday and Friday as a southwesterly flow develops ushering even warmer weather, giving the highest temperatures experienced so far this summer season. Heat warnings will likely be issued this afternoon. Cooler temperatures will occur along parts of the coast, where winds blow onshore. Reduce your risk. Schedule outdoor activities during the coolest parts of the day. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-18T05:49:02-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-17T13:50:02-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1679660438.2020

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A hot and humid airmass remains in place over parts of southern Manitoba today. Daytime highs in the low 30s combined with high humidity will result in humidex values in the upper 30s today. A cold front moving through the region Wednesday night will flush out the humidity and bring cooler air into the region for the rest of the week. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Watch for the effects of heat illness: swelling, rash, cramps, fainting, heat exhaustion, heat stroke and the worsening of some health conditions. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. For more information on heat and your health: - Visit Manitoba Health at: http://www.manitoba.ca/health/publichealth/environmentalhealth/heat.html. - Call Health Links – Info Santé at 204-788-8200 or toll-free at 1-888-315-9257. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-18T02:01:46-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-17T10:02:46-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0570390935.2020

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: At 1:48 p.m. CDT (2:48 p.m. EDT), Environment Canada meteorologists are tracking a severe thunderstorm capable of producing very strong wind gusts and up to nickel size hail. ### Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles.

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: An extended period of very warm to hot weather is expected. Time span: continuing into Friday and possibly Saturday. Maximum daytime temperatures: 30 to 35 degrees Celsius (Humidex 36 to 39) on Thursday and Friday. Cooler conditions are expected along parts of the coast. Minimum overnight temperatures: 18 to 21 degrees Celsius. Locations: New Brunswick. Remarks: Very high temperatures will dominate over New Brunswick for the next several days. The warmest conditions are expected to occur over most areas on Thursday and Friday with cooler temperatures over northwestern parts of the province on Saturday. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of severe thunderstorms that may be capable of producing strong wind gusts and large hail. Hazards: - Damaging wind gusts of 90 to 110 km/h - Quarter to ping pong ball size hail - Risk of a tornado Locations: Portions of far Northern Ontario including Big Trout Lake, Webequie and Winisk River Provincial Park. Timing: This afternoon into this evening. ### Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Locally heavy rain is also possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm. For more information: http://www.emergencymanagementontario.ca/english/beprepared/beprepared.html.
Expires: 2020-06-18T02:03:26-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-17T17:14:26-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0303306771.2020
Area: Big Trout Lake - Kasabonika, Summer Beaver - Wunnummin Lake - Kingfisher Lake, Webequie
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of dangerous thunderstorms that may be capable of producing damaging wind gusts, damaging hail and torrential rain. A cold front tracking eastwards across southern Manitoba is expected to trigger scattered to numerous thunderstorms late this afternoon and evening. These thunderstorms will rapidly become severe. This severe thunderstorm watch may be upgraded to a tornado watch later this afternoon as conditions continue to evolve and are closely monitored. The threat for severe thunderstorms will diminish late this evening as the cold front exits the province. ### Remember, severe thunderstorms can produce tornadoes. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-18T08:06:27-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-17T17:49:27-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2505160138.2020

properties.Title: Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of squalls with wind gusts up to 35 knots, frequent lightning and hail. A cold front tracking eastwards across southern Manitoba is expected to trigger scattered to numerous thunderstorms late this afternoon and evening. The threat for severe thunderstorms will diminish late this evening as the cold front exits the province. ### Large hail can damage vessels and cause injury. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. For more information monitor Canadian Coast Guard radio or Weatheradio stations.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: An area of showers and thunderstorms will soak the region this morning with many areas receiving 25 mm from thunderstorms. Locally higher rainfall amounts of 30 to 50 mm are possible in localities that receive a couple thunderstorms in a row. The thunderstorms are expected to move out or weaken later this morning. However another area of showers and thunderstorms from Southern Manitoba may move into the region later today, with additional rainfall amounts possible. Environment Canada is closely monitoring this situation. Watches or warnings may be issued later today as needed. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-18T03:59:33-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-17T15:08:33-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2150795985.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of hot weather is expected for the end of the week. Time span: Thursday and Friday. Maximum Temperature Thursday: 30 degrees Celsius (Humidex 32) Minimum Temperature Thursday night: 17 to 20 degrees Celsius Maximum Temperature Friday: 32 degrees Celsius (Humidex 36) Locations: Prince Edward Island Remarks: A warm airmass will move into Prince Edward Island today giving maximum temperatures inland near 26 degrees Celsius. Hot weather is expected on Thursday and Friday as a southwesterly flow develops ushering even warmer weather. Heat warning will likely be required this afternoon. Cooler temperatures will occur along parts of the coast, where winds blow onshore. Reduce your risk. Schedule outdoor activities during the coolest parts of the day. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-18T05:48:26-00:00

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Humidex values reaching 26 are expected for the next 2 days. A prolonged period of above normal temperatures and high humidex values is expected in the Kugluktuk area beginning today and continuing into Thursday before coming to an end by Friday. Temperatures for the region will approach or exceed 24 degrees Celsius both days, with an overnight low of 16 degrees Celsius forecast for Wednesday night. The current record high temperature for Kugluktuk on June 17 is 24.1 degrees, set in 1991. Records for this area began in 1930. ### Watch for the effects of heat illness: swelling, rash, cramps, fainting, heat exhaustion, heat stroke and the worsening of some health conditions. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-18T05:10:07-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of dangerous thunderstorms that may be capable of producing damaging wind gusts, large hail and heavy rain. Severe thunderstorms are possible this morning as a low pressure system tracks into the region from the United States. ### Very strong wind gusts can damage buildings, down trees and blow large vehicles off the road. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-18T02:33:20-00:00
